intro: Arabidopsis stricta var. bracteata, commonly known as the bracteate mustard, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It is a member of the Brassicaceae family, characterized by its small, cruciform flowers and capsule fruits. The plant typically grows to a height of 10–30 cm and has linear, glabrous leaves. Its flowering period occurs in the spring and early summer, and it produces small, yellowish flowers that attract pollinators. The variety bracteata is distinguished by the presence of bracts beneath the inflorescence, which are modified leaves.
